Award.AwardTitle: MRI-ACQUISITION OF A SHARED MULTI-COLLECTOR INDUCTIVELY COUPLED MASS SPECTROMETER (MC-ICP-MS) TO BENEFIT TEACHING, FEDERAL, STATE, AND NATIONAL RESEARCH NEEDS IN THE ARCTIC
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) to establish the first multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (MC-ICP-MS) facility in Alaska. This new instrument will be part of the Alaska Isotope Facility (AIF) and will provide support to recruit a new full-time, expert research faculty member at UAF, trained in using MC-ICP-MS. These new resources will be available to train students and researchers from across the UAF campus, as well as other academic institutions both in and outside of Alaska. The facility will serve researchers from state and federal agencies, including those from the U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Army Corp of Engineers and U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service. AIF, the University of Alaska Museum of the North and the Center of Alaska Native Health Research, will provide high quality education and outreach opportunities involving the public, K-12 students, rural high school teachers, undergraduate and graduate students. The new facility will allow chemical analyses of samples, supporting research projects to better understand the migration of salmon and other commercially important fish species, to reveal the migration patterns of ancient and modern animals in the Arctic and to advance our ability to identify sources of heavy metal contamination to the subsistence food web in Alaska, which is critical to the culture and health of Alaska Native people.

This new research facility will provide cutting-edge research techniques to those studying environmental changes in the Arctic and will enhance existing federal investments in the Arctic. Research areas to be immediately enabled include research into migration patterns of economically and culturally important animals in both Arctic aquatic and terrestrial realms, such as salmon, bison and caribou, in response to environmental changes. This new instrument will also support hydrologic studies in the Arctic, which in turn are linked to understanding permafrost dynamics and the release of important greenhouse gases, such and methane and carbon dioxide, to the atmosphere. In the marine realm, the new instrumentation will enable research to study elements that are biologically necessary and can limit or co-limit productivity in parts of the ocean and others that are toxic and can negatively affect higher trophic levels when biomagnified through food webs, such as mercury. This area has particular cultural relevance for Alaska Native communities that rely on subsistence resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have established a state-of-the-art, analytical facility for measuring the isotope composition of heavier elements, such as strontium, at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) campus. Strontium isotope ratios can be used in a wide variety of ecological, paleoecological and archeological studies to track (geolocate) the movement of animals and people. This new research facility has initially specialized in the measurement of strontium isotope ratios of samples and has focused on promoting a series of initial ?flagship? projects. In partnership with state and federal agencies (e.g. National Parks Service, NOAA, Alaska Department of Fish and Game) in Alaska, these projects have included tracking the movement of an endangered beluga whale population in the cook-inlet, Alaska to help identify habitats that could be protected. We are also using strontium isotopes to track the movements of caribou, ancient people and extinct species, including mammoths and steppe bison. These data are critical to help understand the behavior of past and present animals and people in the vast and remote expense of Alaska, where it would be logistically challenging to employ other techniques for tracking mobility. To aid this approach the facility has supported the production of a strontium isotope base-map (isoscape) for the whole of Alaska. Led by graduate student research projects, this was established by conducting measurements of the teeth from modern, non-migratory rodents from across Alaska. This base-map is being published openly to allow further researchers to compare to measurements from their organism of interest to better understand movement ecology. This can be successfully achieved by analyzing tissues that grow incrementally and preserve a record of movement change over time (e.g. tooth enamel). The new research facility has successfully recruited and trained a new member of staff to oversee the long-term care and function of the instrumentation as part of Alaska Isotope Facility. The facility is also supporting a wide array of graduate student research projects and data from the facility has been included in presentations at national and international conferences as well as in peer-reviewed publications. The new facility is regularly included in tours of research facilities at UAF and has also been included in a suite of classes. This new instrumentation has substantially expanded the research and teaching capabilities in Alaska and at the Alaska Isotope Facility and is established and ready for use by researchers.
